awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Extending A Coherent Gateway to STEM Teaching and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
There is compelling evidence that introductory gateway courses are often significant barriers to student success, persistence, and graduation in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM).  Drawing on work supported by the Association of American Universities, this collaborative R&D project is designed to implement an innovative teaching and learning model, Three-Dimensional (3D) Learning, and investigate the factors (e.g., supports and challenges) affecting the adoption and implementation of instructional innovation in introductory and upper level courses in STEM.   The approach is based on an adaptation of the National Research Council's document, A Framework for K-12 Science Education, for postsecondary education.   Rather than focusing on developing faculty awareness and implementation of high impact practices as a means to transform STEM courses, the 3D Learning framework focuses on engaging faculty in identifying core ideas in the disciplines, including scientific practice in the classroom, and incorporating crosscutting scientific concepts in course materials with the goal of building faculty capacity and departmental/institutional infrastructure to improve student learning.  The project concentrates on two major efforts:  (1) the propagation of 3D Learning, development and validation of assessment tools, and implementation of faculty support structures across Michigan State University and its partner institutions, Grand Valley State University, Florida International University, and Kansas State University and (2) research using a variety of methods to examine how instructional innovation is adopted and implemented across different disciplines, department cultures, and institutional ecologies and their affect on student outcomes. 

The project focuses on faculty as key change agents in higher education and draws on the literature on institutional change that emphasizes the importance of the human, social, and cultural capital of individuals in establishing and sustaining institutional change and the propagation of instructional innovation in the classroom.    The quantitative and qualitative mixed methods research project is designed to identify factors and conditions that support or prevent faculty from broadly adopting and implementing 3D Learning.  By examining differential levels of adoption and implementation of 3D Learning across disciplines and institutions, the study will test assumptions found in the theoretical and empirical research literature on faculty development and instructional change.  The research team will use student assessments, classroom observation, surveys, and interviews with students to identify, track, and examine how these different levels of adoption and implementation affect student outcomes, such as persistence, motivation, and knowledge (e.g.,  core ideas in the disciplines, scientific practices, and crosscutting concepts in the sciences).

por.por_cntn:
The “Extending A Coherent Gateway to STEM Teaching and Learning” collaborative project aimed to increase the use of 3-Dimensional Learning (3DL) in college science courses across four institutions ranging from comprehensive Masters level to Research 1. It remains a sad fact that many STEM courses,  particularly at the introductory level, are barriers for large numbers of students, who either lack the background or the support to succeed in the present environment. Traditional science instruction focuses on learning science as gaining knowledge and thus treats science as a set of facts or rote calculations to be memorized. In contrast, 3DL integrates core science concepts (core ideas) with how science knowledge is constructed and used (science practices) and the lenses through which we can view science knowledge (cross-cutting concepts). The 3D approach to learning is grounded in the research literature on best practices in the teaching and learning of science to support students in developing a deep understanding and use of knowledge. Two foundational activities central to this project were a 3DL-focused faculty development program and the development of a protocol for characterizing the extent of 3D instruction in classrooms. Research was conducted to investigate 1) The uptake of 3DL in gateway courses, by characterizing both the types of assessments and the classroom instruction, 2)  How 3DL impacts student learning and perceptions of their learning, and 3) How faculty perceive the rewards and barriers to implementing 3DL. Over the course of this project, more than 50,000 students were impacted, and over 70 faculty engaged in cohort-based, cross-institutional professional development.  Key findings from the project include a noted increase in the use of 3DL in first-year Chemistry, Biology, and Physics courses over the time of the project and improved student performance for students in 3DL sections of courses in terms of ability to construct quality explanations of phenomena, fewer DFWs, higher scores on common assessments, and decreased grade gaps for underrepresented populations of students. Students in 3DL courses perceived that they were using their knowledge to reason about phenomena, whereas in traditional courses students believed their role was to memorize information. Another outcome was that by incorporating 3DL into their classes faculty are also likely to use student-centered instructional practices (which are often discussed as “active learning”). 

Despite all the advantages and positive outcomes of 3DL, it is not something that most college faculty have encountered in their own education, thus effective faculty development is crucial to successful implementation. This project also yielded several key findings related to successful faculty development. It became clear that developing assessments that evaluated both content knowledge and science practices was crucial. This provided faculty with a framework for writing better assessment items and the impetus to include 3DL in their classroom instruction to ensure that students were able to answer these types of questions. Further, faculty indicated that the 3DL framework provided a meaningful way for them to align their identity as a scientist with their roles as teachers, as in a 3DL classroom they are not focused on students memorizing facts but rather on teaching students how to think as scientists. However, a major barrier for most faculty in implementing 3DL is the additional time and effort it takes as they move to this new approach. It takes more class time to have students apply their knowledge and explain phenomena and it takes more time to develop 3DL assessments than it does a typical worksheet or multiple choice test. Therefore it is critical if we are to more fully realize the benefits that 3DL has for student success, for colleges to value and reward the additional time and effort 3DL instruction requires and align their evaluation and promotion policies to reflect this.
